summary: The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California today entered a final judgment against Oracle, Inc. (ORCL) for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Rule 17a-3 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in San Diego, California, alleges that Oracle violated its duty to preserve evidence related to Oracle's alleged misconduct in connection with its hardware support business.  According to the complaint, Oracle's failure to preserve documents related to the hardware support businesses resulted in the loss of at least 235 documents.  In addition, the complaint alleges that Hurd failed to preserve relevant documents relating to HPE's and Oracle’s unlawful diversion of customers' reasons for canceling or not renewing contracts with Oracle in 2010.  Oracle also alleges that, as a result of this conduct, HPE and Hurd could not show any prejudice as to why any of the documents were lost or why they were not produced in the timely manner required by Rule 37(e).  The complaint further alleges that HPE failed to produce any documents relevant to the litigation when it was in litigation with Oracle.  HPE also failed to provide Oracle with a copy of a technical support agreement that it signed with Terix, despite the fact that Terix had provided Oracle with copies of the technical support agreements.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's Complaint, Oracle and HPE consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of the federal securities laws, ordering them to comply with the court's order, and ordering the destruction of any documents that may be relevant to this litigation.  On May 6, 2018, the court granted Oracle's request for a temporary restraining order against Hurd from destroying documents in the anticipation or conduct of litigation, and ordered HPE to produce documents that were relevant to that litigation in order to determine whether or not to preserve them for future use in the future.   The court also granted HPE the right to request a preliminary injunction against further violations of Rule 37e, ordering it to provide an accounting of the material that was lost in the litigation, as well as an explanation for why it had not produced any documents in its possession.  Finally, the Court granted the request for an expedited hearing on June 15, 2018.
